title: Swollen Inguinal Node
content: I am 38 years old white female. 14 Sept /05  I noticed my right inguinal node swollen.  15 Sept /05 I saw my gynecologist.  His diagnosis was a possible cervical infection ( I had pain on the right side of the cervix when examined ) and he prescribed dalacin vaginal cream X7 days. Not noticing improvement, 23 Sept/05 I saw an emergency room doctor. He confirmed it was an inguinal adenopathy ( moveable ),and noticed peasize node in my armpit (which he did not consider significant ). He prescribed Cefadroxil antibiotic bid X 7days,and said the node may never go away ? There has been no significant decrease in the node size. Upon awakening it seems slightly smaller and more diffuse but as the day goes on seems to get larger and more distinct. It is moveable , slightly sensitive to touch if pressed and there is on occasion mild discomfort in that area.How long can a node stay swollen after infection? Does this sound serious? Should it be biopsied : if so when would it be reasonable to do so ? Are there disadvantages to doing a biopsy ? Please answer. I am a mother of 2 boys and I am so worried and losing sleep over this. author: Dr. A. De la Guerra  Medical Doctor Posts: 70 Joined: Fri Aug 26, 2005 8:00 pm Gender: Male Location: Lima, Peru  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. De la Guerra       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hello Shosh, I don’t have information about the size of your node, however inguinal nodes larger than 1.5 cm should be considered abnormal. By far, the most common cause of lymph node swelling is infection; as a rule, when swelling appears suddenly and is painful, it is usually caused by infection.  Regarding your question about how long can a node stay swollen after infection, frequently the pain might disappear in a couple of days, but, depending on several factors (like type and severity of infection), the node may not return to normal size for several weeks. Most lymph nodes which come up because of a recent infection tend to resolve after a month or so.  Further investigation may be necessary if the node persists for more than 2 months or continues to get larger, feel hard, irregular, or fixed in place.  The possibility that a single enlarged node can be cancer is less than 1%, even less if it’s in the groin.  I don't think you have to worry so much.

title: Return of Inguinal Node (?) following biopsy
content: As follow-up to my original post: I had a biopsy done November 1, 2005 of an inguinal node. The results were negative (ie. inflammatory in nature, approximately 1cm in size as stated by the doctor upon its removal).  Following the surgery I had a hard lump in the area which the surgeon called "fat necrosis" and which he said would disappear in 6 weeks and "all would go back to normal."  It has now been 5 months and I still have a small lump in the same area (right groin), moveable although more attached than the original node, and variable in size (approximately 1.5 to 2 cm by 1 cm, smaller upon waking and larger, more distinct as the day goes on).   If the cause of the original node was inflammatory, why would a new node appear?  Is this a result of the surgery or does this mean the original inflammation is still active?  If this is a persistent inflammation, how critical is it that the source be found and how should I go about doing this?  As a note, I did have an ectopic pregnancy in my right fallopian tube 4 years ago with secondary tubal scarring.  Any insight into this matter would be greatly appreciated.  Sincerely, shosh.

author: Dr. A. De la Guerra  Medical Doctor Posts: 70 Joined: Fri Aug 26, 2005 8:00 pm Gender: Male Location: Lima, Peru  Contact:   Contact Dr. A. De la Guerra       Yahoo Messenger
title: [no title]
content: Hello Shosh,  Any condition that cuts down blood flow to a wound has the potential to cause necrosis (tissue death), due to deprived oxygen supply to cells (called ischemia). When this happens in the subcutaneous fat is known as fat necrosis, which is most commonly caused by injure to tissues during surgery. When fat necrosis occurs, death cells clump together within a pseudocapsule (false pouch); then eventually it will melt and reabsorb.  In sum, fat necrosis is the formation of a small area of scar tissue caused by ischemic necrosis of subcutaneous fat with no involvement of the overlying skin. The lesion might appear as a lump, usually very hard and firm. Less often, the lump has some fluid inside (called lipid or oil cysts). Both types are locally circumscribed masses; also both may calcify, becoming harder and mimicking malignant tumors.  Usually fat necrosis soft on its own and is removed over time by the body. The lump disappears after a few weeks, but sometimes takes several months. Some doctors will recommend massages to the lump, others will suggest ultrasound therapy to help it liquefy faster. On occasions, surgical removal is necessary, especially if it becomes infected.  A new lump arising in the same place where surgery was done to remove a benign lymphadenopathy is more likely to be a consequence of the formation of new tissue in the process of wound healing, or due to a minor complication like fat necrosis.  Other complication of lymph node surgery is the formation of lymph or lymphatic cysts, also called lymph-filled cysts, lymphocysts or lymphoceles. After surgical trauma to lymphatic vessels, lymph fluid leaks inside the surgical bed, with the subsequent formation of a cystic mass. Lymphoceles are commonly seen following surgical transection of large amounts of lymphatic tissue, or because of inadequate ligation of lymphatic vessels during lymph node dissection (cancer surgery). Occurrence of lymphoceles after removal of a single lymph node is extremely unusual.  Apparently you have a fat necrosis sequel. If the lump doesn’t cause you any symptoms I think you can wait a few more months to see if it goes away. If it bothers you, check with your surgeon, he will decide what the best way to handle the situation is.  Hope you find the information useful.  Sincerely,  Dr. Alberto de la Guerra.

title: Re: blood from ears
content: Hi, Normally, i am skeptical about offering rare diagnoses (for the simple reason that common things always occur commonly!). But in this instance, the description of your uncle's symptoms that you have provided, somehow led me to think of a rare diagnosis! -- The 'Glomus Jugulare Tumor'. A type of Chemodectoma, arising from the skull base, at or near the jugular bulb. This has been reported to give rise to a feeling of a loud pulsing in the ear.Intermittent bleeding from the ear is also known. Chemodectomas are benign in 95 per cent of cases. Rarely malignant Chemodectomas do occur and are known to metastasize widely. I hope this information may be of use to you.Best wishes!

title: Re: Patela Nodule
content: Hello,  Prepatellar bursitis causes pain and swelling in front of the kneecap during acute phase of inflammation. If the condition is repeated and following recurrent attacks of acute bursitis, thickening of the bursa tissue occurs and folds of bursa tissue are formed and felt as lumps.  MRI is the test of choice and any suspicious signals would direct further investigations. So, I assume that his doctor did not see any malignancy concerning features on your father͗s MRI.  However, considering his personal history of prostate cancer and assuming that this a recent swelling, it is better to  do a new PSA and a bone scan to exclude serious causes like bone metastasis although unlikely if MRI results are very clear and not just suggestive  I advise you to discuss these possibilities with his doctor to be reassured that he has excluded all serious causes for this swelling. You also should observe this swelling and any changes like increase in size should be reported to his doctor.  Hope you find this information useful. Best regards.

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: Re: Lumps in Multiple Body Parts
content: Hello, Breast lump appears to be unrelated to other lumps in your body, so we are going to discuss each separately.   Regarding the recently developed breast lump that was confirmed by mammography and US, close follow up and serial radiological examination is essential considering your past history of breast lump and biopsy. So, I advise you to follow up with your doctor for proper clinical examination, evaluating the need of pathological examination of this lump.   Regarding lumps developed on the external genitalia, it sounds to be Bartholin's abscess or cyst. Bartholin's glands are glands in the vaginal lips that once infected become swollen and painful. In some occasions following infection blockage in their main duct occurs, and a cyst develops. Cysts are felt as a painless swelling. Bacterial infection is the common cause and is treated with antibiotics.   Herpes virus infection exclusion is essential and since you have been tested negative twice its possibility became remote. Tests for herepes infection include viral culture (still the diagnostic test of choice for HSV skin infections) and blood tests (serological testing for AB is commonly used). PCR analysis is not routinely done and is used for more serious types of infections (e.g. suspected CNS infection). Tumors in this part of the body (benign or cancerous) are extremely rare.  Regarding lesions developed in oral cavity and ears, infectious causes should be first excluded including viral, bacterial and fungal (remote) causes.  Herpes simplex is more likely to give symptoms similar to yours and it is true they develop following periods of stress.   Genital herpes is caused by a different type of the same virus that causes gingivostomatitis, recurrent herpes simplex virus infection can occur on the tongue. HPV should be in mind although your presentation is not typically for HPV infection and its sequels but being positive for HPV, it is of consideration. Cancer in the tongue usually develops as a painless bump on one side of the tongue.  Other possible causes include bacterial infections, immune system problem or an allergy.   Possible causes can be determined after careful history taking and examination. Please follow up with your doctor and discuss with him these causes in your next visit.  Please keep us updated. Best regards.

title: Re: Lump on inner thigh
content: Hello, It is probably a lymph node (inguinal) as it occurs in a lymph node region. Inguinal nodes are usually considered abnormal when larger than 1.5 cm.  Common causes of enlargement include infections in the area drained by this lymph node like the leg or foot, genitourinary or the lower part of the abdominal wall. author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  It will be more helpful if you can send more details about the investigations done to search for the primary tumor e.g. scans, tumor markers, of utmost importance the pathological details for the excised tumor mass etc.  Brain metastases of unknown primary origin are commonly seen of a primary lung cancer, while breast cancer, colon carcinoma, and melanoma are followed in frequency.  She has a history of both breast and melanoma cancer which as mentioned before could be a source for metastatic brain lesions. Multiple lesions are seen in brain metastases of both lung and melanoma cancers.  Although the prognosis is generally poor, therapeutic options are individualized and considerations like the general, neurologic status, number and location of brain metastases, and of utmost importance the tumor sensitivity to radiation and chemotherapy.   Treatment options of surgically resectable brain lesions become safer, less invasive, and more effective than many years ago.   A better survival is expected in patients with resectable tumors.  Hope this information is useful. Best regards. Keep us updated.

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Dear HappyMommy,  Clinical examination is essential for the initial evaluation of any lump. If these lesions are though to be lipomas, then the condition could be of Familial Multiple Lipomas. When a of groups of fat cells in the subcutaneous tissues  grow spontaneously forming fatty lumps under the skin, the condition is known as lipoma.   The condition is benign. This condition is thought to be of genetic factor.  Patients with this disease present with multiple small fatty subcutaneous nodules which are usually painless. Their number and distribution is different, mainly on the arms, forearms, legs and trunk but may be also in the neck, face and buttocks.   There different variables of the disease like Adiposis Dolorosa when there is a large painful lipomatous lesion. These lesions can be easily diagnosed clinically. US can help in the diagnosis.  If these lesions are suspicious NFAC can confirm the diagnosis or excisional biopsy.  The disease seldom needs treatment, surgical removal is recommended only for large lesions causing problems.  Hope you find this information useful. Best regards,

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  The inguinal lymph nodes are situated in the crease between the leg and pelvis (more on the outside of that crease, ie, laterally).   They drain the penis, scrotum, vulva, vagina, perineum, gluteal region, lower abdominal wall, lower anal canal.  Common causes of enlargement include infections of the leg or foot, STDs (eg, herpes simplex virus, gonococcal infection, syphilis, chancroid, granuloma inguinale, lymphogranuloma venereum), lymphoma, pelvic malignancy, bubonic plague.  Nodes are generally considered to be normal if they are up to 1 cm in diameter; however, some authors suggest that inguinal nodes larger than 1.5 cm should be considered abnormal.  If it is painful or tender this indicate infection or inflammation.   The pain you feel while you cough or sneeze means that there is irritation of the peritoneum due to inflammation of any pelvic organ whether GI or Gynecological commonly seen in appendicitis.  Hope you find this information useful.  Do not forget that, here is no replacement to a direct clinical examination. Only by complete history and physical examination, the correct diagnosis can be reached.   Best regards,

author: Dr. Safaa Mahmoud  Medical Doctor Posts: 1434 Joined: Sat Jan 04, 2003 7:53 am
title: [no title]
content: Hello,  I have read your other posts and your hormone profile is very suggestive of Cushing's syndrome, although your dexamethasone suppression test was normal  as I understood.  The blood tests for your hormones should be repeated during periods of less stress as cortisol is a stress induced hormone. If it returns back to normal then other possibilities like poly cystic ovary syndrome PCOS should be excluded.  Females with PCOS experience any of the following symptoms:  - Menstrual irregularity or absence of menstruation,  - Irregular vaginal bleeding,  Due to inadequate progesterone. - Fertility problems  - Increased growth of hair Acne, oily skin, or dandruff  Due to excessive production of androgen (testosterone and DHEAS) - Osteoprotic changes results in bony aches and high serum calcium level. - Pelvic pain  - Obesity  - High Cholesterol  - High blood pressure    -functional hypothyrodism Type 2 Diabetes  Pelvic  US is used in the diagnosis. In this case high cortisol and prolactin could be also due to related stressful conditions.  If your hormonal profile still shows high levels of cortisol, prolactin I advise you to have an MRI or CT to rule out pituitary tumors.  Follow up with your doctor is essential, you can discuss with him these possibilities.   Keep us updated,  Best regards,

title: New CUP Diagnosis
content: I have been diagnosed with a CUP. I have had surgery and the reccommended course of treatment is radiation therapy. However, when pressed my radiation doctor hedges on radiation being absolutely required. Here is some of his comments to me.  Thanks for you questions and I do appreciate how overwhelming this must be. I did speak to the pathologist. Apparently the pathology was not labeled properly and so nodal counts which are usually done on neck dissections were not done. One node was involved with cancer and there was no extracapsular spread. The size was 3.5 x 5.0 cm on the CT scan which means it is a stage N2a. Your base of tongue biopsy also shows dysplasia which is suggestive  of an underlying malignancy in the base of tongue.  Most people in the country would recommend treatment unless the node was under 3 cm. It is difficult to find information to tell us what the rate of developing a cancer in the throat is but one paper said that it was 44% in patients who only had neck dissection compared with 8% for those who had radiation. We will be presenting your films, slides, and history tomorrow at our tumor board. I will certainly call you after that to let you know what was said.  There is no way to tell whether radiation improves survival because as I said many patients have other medical problems. My feeling is that you are young, healthy and generally in better health than many patients with this diagnosis. You apparently have only one node involved. The survival rate that is often quoted is for patients who present with all forms of neck disease.   My question is due to the side effects of radiation, some not so pleasant, what is the down side to doing nothing but having frequent checkups over the next two years or so.

author: Dr. Jeffrey Gordon  Medical Doctor Posts: 127 Joined: Sun Jan 05, 2003 5:22 pm
title: CUP
content: My apologies for the delay in your getting a response to your question.  There has been a backlog of questions here at The lounge.  We are endeavoring to respond to all questions, including old ones.  As more of us are responding to questions, we hope to be able to respond to new questions in a timely manner.  I hope that you will visit The Lounge again and that you next experience here will be better than your last.  Your situation is not straight foward and there is not particular right or wrong answers to it.  The upside of treatment is that it could well be of benefit in treating the cancer, especially if there is not much cancer present.  The downside of therapy is that you could have various side effects without much benefit.  The upside of monitoring the situation closely is that treatment could be offered at a time that it is more strongly indicated (and thus the risks of treatment are outweighed by the benefits).  The downside of monitoring the situation is that an opportunity to treat the cancer may be missed or that doing treatment later may be less effective than doing treatment up front because there has been more time for cancer to grow and to spread.  Could you let us know what has developed?  Jeffrey A. Gordon,  M.D.

content: Hi Ctri, I agree with your doctor. There is probably no need to worry about this. Lymph nodes enlarge when they fight infection. That is actually their primary function.
